qas.question: What explains the difficulty in a system containing availability, consistency, and partition tolerance guarantees?
How many guarantees will most databases tolerate?
What is used to offer a balance in guarantees?
What can't explain the difficulty in a system containing availability, consistency, and partition tolerance guarantees?
How many guarantees will most databases destroy?
What can satisfy all guarantees at the same time?
What is used to discourage eventual consistency?

plausible_answers.text: massively distributed databases with high partition tolerance

qas.question: What has had low demand in recent years?

context: In recent years there was a high demand for <b7_0>massively distributed databases with high partition tolerance<b7_0/> but according to <a0_0><b3_0>the CAP theorem<b3_0/><a0_0/> it is impossible for a distributed system to simultaneously provide consistency, availability and partition tolerance guarantees. <b5_0>A distributed system<b5_0/> can satisfy any <a1_0><b4_0>two<b4_0/><a1_0/> of these guarantees at the same time, but not all three. For that reason many <b6_0>NoSQL databases<b6_0/> are using what is called <a2_0>eventual consistency<a2_0/> to provide both availability and partition tolerance guarantees with a reduced level of data consistency.
